refs.DescribeEndpointsRequest$MaxResults: Optional. Max number of endpoints, up to twenty, that will be returned at one time.
refs.DvbNitSettings$NetworkId: The numeric value placed in the Network Information Table (NIT).
refs.DvbNitSettings$NitInterval: The number of milliseconds between instances of this table in the output transport stream.
refs.DvbSdtSettings$SdtInterval: The number of milliseconds between instances of this table in the output transport stream.
refs.DvbSubDestinationSettings$BackgroundOpac: Specifies the opacity of the background rectangle. 255 is opaque; 0 is transparent. Leaving this parameter blank is equivalent to setting it to 0 (transparent). All burn-in and DVB-Sub font settings must match.
refs.DvbSubDestinationSettings$FontOpacity:
Specifies the opacity of the burned-in captions. 255 is opaque; 0 is transparent.
All burn-in and DVB-Sub font settings must match.
refs.DvbSubDestinationSettings$FontResolution:
Font resolution in DPI (dots per inch); default is 96 dpi.
All burn-in and DVB-Sub font settings must match.
refs.DvbSubDestinationSettings$FontSize: A positive integer indicates the exact font size in points. Set to 0 for automatic font size selection. All burn-in and DVB-Sub font settings must match.
refs.DvbSubDestinationSettings$OutlineSize: Specifies font outline size in pixels. This option is not valid for source captions that are either 608/embedded or teletext. These source settings are already pre-defined by the caption stream. All burn-in and DVB-Sub font settings must match.
refs.DvbSubDestinationSettings$ShadowOpacity: Specifies the opacity of the shadow. 255 is opaque; 0 is transparent. Leaving this parameter blank is equivalent to setting it to 0 (transparent). All burn-in and DVB-Sub font settings must match.
refs.DvbSubDestinationSettings$ShadowXOffset: Specifies the horizontal offset of the shadow relative to the captions in pixels. A value of -2 would result in a shadow offset 2 pixels to the left. All burn-in and DVB-Sub font settings must match.
refs.DvbSubDestinationSettings$ShadowYOffset: Specifies the vertical offset of the shadow relative to the captions in pixels. A value of -2 would result in a shadow offset 2 pixels above the text. All burn-in and DVB-Sub font settings must match.
refs.DvbSubDestinationSettings$XPosition: Specifies the horizontal position of the caption relative to the left side of the output in pixels. A value of 10 would result in the captions starting 10 pixels from the left of the output. If no explicit x_position is provided, the horizontal caption position will be determined by the alignment parameter. This option is not valid for source captions that are STL, 608/embedded or teletext. These source settings are already pre-defined by the caption stream. All burn-in and DVB-Sub font settings must match.
refs.DvbSubDestinationSettings$YPosition: Specifies the vertical position of the caption relative to the top of the output in pixels. A value of 10 would result in the captions starting 10 pixels from the top of the output. If no explicit y_position is provided, the caption will be positioned towards the bottom of the output. This option is not valid for source captions that are STL, 608/embedded or teletext. These source settings are already pre-defined by the caption stream. All burn-in and DVB-Sub font settings must match.
refs.DvbSubSourceSettings$Pid: When using DVB-Sub with Burn-In or SMPTE-TT, use this PID for the source content. Unused for DVB-Sub passthrough. All DVB-Sub content is passed through, regardless of selectors.
refs.DvbTdtSettings$TdtInterval: The number of milliseconds between instances of this table in the output transport stream.
refs.Eac3Settings$Bitrate: Average bitrate in bits/second. Valid bitrates depend on the coding mode.
refs.Eac3Settings$Dialnorm: Sets the dialnorm for the output. If blank and input audio is Dolby Digital Plus, dialnorm will be passed through.
refs.Eac3Settings$SampleRate: Sample rate in hz. Sample rate is always 48000.
refs.EmbeddedSourceSettings$Source608ChannelN: Specifies the 608/708 channel number within the video track from which to extract captions. Unused for passthrough.
refs.EmbeddedSourceSettings$Source608TrackNum: Specifies the video track index used for extracting captions. The system only supports one input video track, so this should always be set to '1'.
refs.FileSourceSettings$TimeDelta: Specifies a time delta in seconds to offset the captions from the source file.
refs.FrameCaptureSettings$FramerateDenominato: Frame capture will encode the first frame of the output stream, then one frame every framerateDenominator/framerateNumerator seconds. For example, settings of framerateNumerator = 1 and framerateDenominator = 3 (a rate of 1/3 frame per second) will capture the first frame, then 1 frame every 3s. Files will be named as filename.n.jpg where n is the 0-based sequence number of each Capture.
refs.FrameCaptureSettings$FramerateNumerator: Frame capture will encode the first frame of the output stream, then one frame every framerateDenominator/framerateNumerator seconds. For example, settings of framerateNumerator = 1 and framerateDenominator = 3 (a rate of 1/3 frame per second) will capture the first frame, then 1 frame every 3s. Files will be named as filename.NNNNNNN.jpg where N is the 0-based frame sequence number zero padded to 7 decimal places.
refs.FrameCaptureSettings$MaxCaptures: Maximum number of captures (encoded jpg output files).
refs.FrameCaptureSettings$Quality: JPEG Quality - a higher value equals higher quality.
refs.H264Settings$Bitrate: Average bitrate in bits/second. Required for VBR, CBR, and ABR. Five megabits can be entered as 5000000 or 5m. Five hundred kilobits can be entered as 500000 or 0.5m. For MS Smooth outputs, bitrates must be unique when rounded down to the nearest multiple of 1000.
refs.H264Settings$FramerateDenominator: When you use the API for transcode jobs that use framerate conversion, specify the framerate as a fraction. For example,  24000 / 1001 = 23.976 fps. Use FramerateDenominator to specify the denominator of this fraction. In this example, use 1001 for the value of FramerateDenominator. When you use the console for transcode jobs that use framerate conversion, provide the value as a decimal number for Framerate. In this example, specify 23.976.
refs.H264Settings$FramerateNumerator: Framerate numerator - framerate is a fraction, e.g. 24000 / 1001 = 23.976 fps.
refs.H264Settings$GopClosedCadence: Frequency of closed GOPs. In streaming applications, it is recommended that this be set to 1 so a decoder joining mid-stream will receive an IDR frame as quickly as possible. Setting this value to 0 will break output segmenting.
refs.H264Settings$HrdBufferInitialFillPercent: Percentage of the buffer that should initially be filled (HRD buffer model).
refs.H264Settings$HrdBufferSize: Size of buffer (HRD buffer model). Five megabits can be entered as 5000000 or 5m. Five hundred kilobits can be entered as 500000 or 0.5m.
refs.H264Settings$MaxBitrate: Maximum bitrate in bits/second (for VBR mode only). Five megabits can be entered as 5000000 or 5m. Five hundred kilobits can be entered as 500000 or 0.5m.
refs.H264Settings$MinIInterval: Enforces separation between repeated (cadence) I-frames and I-frames inserted by Scene Change Detection. If a scene change I-frame is within I-interval frames of a cadence I-frame, the GOP is shrunk and/or stretched to the scene change I-frame. GOP stretch requires enabling lookahead as well as setting I-interval. The normal cadence resumes for the next GOP. This setting is only used when Scene Change Detect is enabled. Note: Maximum GOP stretch = GOP size + Min-I-interval - 1
refs.H264Settings$NumberBFramesBetweenReferen: Number of B-frames between reference frames.
refs.H264Settings$NumberReferenceFrames: Number of reference frames to use. The encoder may use more than requested if using B-frames and/or interlaced encoding.
refs.H264Settings$Slices: Number of slices per picture. Must be less than or equal to the number of macroblock rows for progressive pictures, and less than or equal to half the number of macroblock rows for interlaced pictures.
refs.H264Settings$Softness: Softness. Selects quantizer matrix, larger values reduce high-frequency content in the encoded image.
refs.H265Settings$Bitrate: Average bitrate in bits/second. Required for VBR, CBR, and ABR. Five megabits can be entered as 5000000 or 5m. Five hundred kilobits can be entered as 500000 or 0.5m. For MS Smooth outputs, bitrates must be unique when rounded down to the nearest multiple of 1000.
refs.H265Settings$FramerateNumerator: Framerate numerator - framerate is a fraction, e.g. 24000 / 1001 = 23.976 fps.
refs.H265Settings$GopClosedCadence: Frequency of closed GOPs. In streaming applications, it is recommended that this be set to 1 so a decoder joining mid-stream will receive an IDR frame as quickly as possible. Setting this value to 0 will break output segmenting.
refs.H265Settings$HrdBufferInitialFillPercent: Percentage of the buffer that should initially be filled (HRD buffer model).
refs.H265Settings$HrdBufferSize: Size of buffer (HRD buffer model). Five megabits can be entered as 5000000 or 5m. Five hundred kilobits can be entered as 500000 or 0.5m.
refs.H265Settings$MaxBitrate: Maximum bitrate in bits/second (for VBR mode only). Five megabits can be entered as 5000000 or 5m. Five hundred kilobits can be entered as 500000 or 0.5m.
refs.H265Settings$MinIInterval: Enforces separation between repeated (cadence) I-frames and I-frames inserted by Scene Change Detection. If a scene change I-frame is within I-interval frames of a cadence I-frame, the GOP is shrunk and/or stretched to the scene change I-frame. GOP stretch requires enabling lookahead as well as setting I-interval. The normal cadence resumes for the next GOP. This setting is only used when Scene Change Detect is enabled. Note: Maximum GOP stretch = GOP size + Min-I-interval - 1
refs.H265Settings$NumberBFramesBetweenReferen: Number of B-frames between reference frames.
refs.H265Settings$NumberReferenceFrames: Number of reference frames to use. The encoder may use more than requested if using B-frames and/or interlaced encoding.
refs.H265Settings$Slices: Number of slices per picture. Must be less than or equal to the number of macroblock rows for progressive pictures, and less than or equal to half the number of macroblock rows for interlaced pictures.
refs.Hdr10Metadata$BluePrimaryX: HDR Master Display Information comes from the color grader and the color grading tools. Range is 0 to 50,000, each increment represents 0.00002 in CIE1931 color coordinate.
refs.Hdr10Metadata$BluePrimaryY: HDR Master Display Information comes from the color grader and the color grading tools. Range is 0 to 50,000, each increment represents 0.00002 in CIE1931 color coordinate.
refs.Hdr10Metadata$GreenPrimaryX: HDR Master Display Information comes from the color grader and the color grading tools. Range is 0 to 50,000, each increment represents 0.00002 in CIE1931 color coordinate.
refs.Hdr10Metadata$GreenPrimaryY: HDR Master Display Information comes from the color grader and the color grading tools. Range is 0 to 50,000, each increment represents 0.00002 in CIE1931 color coordinate.
refs.Hdr10Metadata$MaxContentLightLevel: Maximum light level among all samples in the coded video sequence, in units of candelas per square meter.
refs.Hdr10Metadata$MaxFrameAverageLightLevel: Maximum average light level of any frame in the coded video sequence, in units of candelas per square meter.
refs.Hdr10Metadata$MaxLuminance: Nominal maximum mastering display luminance in units of of 0.0001 candelas per square meter.
refs.Hdr10Metadata$MinLuminance: Nominal minimum mastering display luminance in units of of 0.0001 candelas per square meter
refs.Hdr10Metadata$RedPrimaryX: HDR Master Display Information comes from the color grader and the color grading tools. Range is 0 to 50,000, each increment represents 0.00002 in CIE1931 color coordinate.
refs.Hdr10Metadata$RedPrimaryY: HDR Master Display Information comes from the color grader and the color grading tools. Range is 0 to 50,000, each increment represents 0.00002 in CIE1931 color coordinate.
refs.Hdr10Metadata$WhitePointX: HDR Master Display Information comes from the color grader and the color grading tools. Range is 0 to 50,000, each increment represents 0.00002 in CIE1931 color coordinate.
refs.Hdr10Metadata$WhitePointY: HDR Master Display Information comes from the color grader and the color grading tools. Range is 0 to 50,000, each increment represents 0.00002 in CIE1931 color coordinate.
refs.HlsGroupSettings$MinSegmentLength: When set, Minimum Segment Size is enforced by looking ahead and back within the specified range for a nearby avail and extending the segment size if needed.
refs.HlsGroupSettings$ProgramDateTimePeriod: Period of insertion of EXT-X-PROGRAM-DATE-TIME entry, in seconds.
refs.HlsGroupSettings$SegmentLength: Length of MPEG-2 Transport Stream segments to create (in seconds). Note that segments will end on the next keyframe after this number of seconds, so actual segment length may be longer.
refs.HlsGroupSettings$SegmentsPerSubdirectory: Number of segments to write to a subdirectory before starting a new one. directoryStructure must be SINGLE_DIRECTORY for this setting to have an effect.
refs.HlsGroupSettings$TimestampDeltaMilliseco: Provides an extra millisecond delta offset to fine tune the timestamps.
refs.Input$FilterStrength: Use Filter strength (FilterStrength) to adjust the magnitude the input filter settings (Deblock and Denoise). The range is -5 to 5. Default is 0.
refs.Input$ProgramNumber: Use Program (programNumber) to select a specific program from within a multi-program transport stream. Note that Quad 4K is not currently supported. Default is the first program within the transport stream. If the program you specify doesn't exist, the transcoding service will use this default.
refs.InputTemplate$FilterStrength: Use Filter strength (FilterStrength) to adjust the magnitude the input filter settings (Deblock and Denoise). The range is -5 to 5. Default is 0.
refs.InputTemplate$ProgramNumber: Use Program (programNumber) to select a specific program from within a multi-program transport stream. Note that Quad 4K is not currently supported. Default is the first program within the transport stream. If the program you specify doesn't exist, the transcoding service will use this default.
refs.InsertableImage$Duration: Use Duration (Duration) to set the time, in milliseconds, for the image to remain on the output video.
refs.InsertableImage$FadeIn: Use Fade in (FadeIut) to set the length, in milliseconds, of the inserted image fade in. If you don't specify a value for Fade in, the image will appear abruptly at the Start time.
refs.InsertableImage$FadeOut: Use Fade out (FadeOut) to set the length, in milliseconds, of the inserted image fade out. If you don't specify a value for Fade out, the image will disappear abruptly at the end of the inserted image duration.
refs.InsertableImage$Height: Specify the Height (Height) of the inserted image. Use a value that is less than or equal to the video resolution height. Leave this setting blank to use the native height of the image.
refs.InsertableImage$ImageX: Use Left (ImageX) to set the distance, in pixels, between the inserted image and the left edge of the frame. Required for BMP, PNG and TGA input.
refs.InsertableImage$ImageY: Use Top (ImageY) to set the distance, in pixels, between the inserted image and the top edge of the video frame. Required for BMP, PNG and TGA input.
refs.InsertableImage$Layer: Use Layer (Layer) to specify how overlapping inserted images appear. Images with higher values of layer appear on top of images with lower values of layer.
refs.InsertableImage$Opacity: Use Opacity (Opacity) to specify how much of the underlying video shows through the inserted image. 0 is transparent and 100 is fully opaque. Default is 50.
refs.InsertableImage$Width: Specify the Width (Width) of the inserted image. Use a value that is less than or equal to the video resolution width. Leave this setting blank to use the native width of the image.
refs.JobSettings$AdAvailOffset: When specified, this offset (in milliseconds) is added to the input Ad Avail PTS time.
refs.JobTemplateSettings$AdAvailOffset: When specified, this offset (in milliseconds) is added to the input Ad Avail PTS time.
refs.ListJobTemplatesRequest$MaxResults: Optional. Number of job templates, up to twenty, that will be returned at one time.
refs.ListJobsRequest$MaxResults: Optional. Number of jobs, up to twenty, that will be returned at one time.
refs.ListPresetsRequest$MaxResults: Optional. Number of presets, up to twenty, that will be returned at one time
refs.ListQueuesRequest$MaxResults: Optional. Number of queues, up to twenty, that will be returned at one time.
refs.M2tsSettings$AudioFramesPerPes: The number of audio frames to insert for each PES packet.
refs.M2tsSettings$Bitrate: The output bitrate of the transport stream in bits per second. Setting to 0 lets the muxer automatically determine the appropriate bitrate. Other common values are 3750000, 7500000, and 15000000.
refs.M2tsSettings$DvbTeletextPid: Packet Identifier (PID) for input source DVB Teletext data to this output. Can be entered as a decimal or hexadecimal value.
refs.M2tsSettings$MaxPcrInterval: Maximum time in milliseconds between Program Clock References (PCRs) inserted into the transport stream.
refs.M2tsSettings$MinEbpInterval: When set, enforces that Encoder Boundary Points do not come within the specified time interval of each other by looking ahead at input video. If another EBP is going to come in within the specified time interval, the current EBP is not emitted, and the segment is "stretched" to the next marker. The lookahead value does not add latency to the system. The Live Event must be configured elsewhere to create sufficient latency to make the lookahead accurate.
refs.M2tsSettings$PatInterval: The number of milliseconds between instances of this table in the output transport stream.
refs.M2tsSettings$PcrPid: Packet Identifier (PID) of the Program Clock Reference (PCR) in the transport stream. When no value is given, the encoder will assign the same value as the Video PID. Can be entered as a decimal or hexadecimal value.
refs.M2tsSettings$PmtInterval: The number of milliseconds between instances of this table in the output transport stream.
refs.M2tsSettings$PmtPid: Packet Identifier (PID) for the Program Map Table (PMT) in the transport stream. Can be entered as a decimal or hexadecimal value.
refs.M2tsSettings$PrivateMetadataPid: Packet Identifier (PID) of the private metadata stream in the transport stream. Can be entered as a decimal or hexadecimal value.
refs.M2tsSettings$ProgramNumber: The value of the program number field in the Program Map Table.
refs.M2tsSettings$Scte35Pid: Packet Identifier (PID) of the SCTE-35 stream in the transport stream. Can be entered as a decimal or hexadecimal value.
refs.M2tsSettings$TransportStreamId: The value of the transport stream ID field in the Program Map Table.
refs.M2tsSettings$VideoPid: Packet Identifier (PID) of the elementary video stream in the transport stream. Can be entered as a decimal or hexadecimal value.
refs.M3u8Settings$AudioFramesPerPes: The number of audio frames to insert for each PES packet.
refs.M3u8Settings$PatInterval: The number of milliseconds between instances of this table in the output transport stream.
refs.M3u8Settings$PcrPid: Packet Identifier (PID) of the Program Clock Reference (PCR) in the transport stream. When no value is given, the encoder will assign the same value as the Video PID. Can be entered as a decimal or hexadecimal value.
refs.M3u8Settings$PmtInterval: The number of milliseconds between instances of this table in the output transport stream.
refs.M3u8Settings$PmtPid: Packet Identifier (PID) for the Program Map Table (PMT) in the transport stream. Can be entered as a decimal or hexadecimal value.
refs.M3u8Settings$PrivateMetadataPid: Packet Identifier (PID) of the private metadata stream in the transport stream. Can be entered as a decimal or hexadecimal value.
refs.M3u8Settings$ProgramNumber: The value of the program number field in the Program Map Table.
refs.M3u8Settings$Scte35Pid: Packet Identifier (PID) of the SCTE-35 stream in the transport stream. Can be entered as a decimal or hexadecimal value.
refs.M3u8Settings$TimedMetadataPid: Packet Identifier (PID) of the timed metadata stream in the transport stream. Can be entered as a decimal or hexadecimal value.
refs.M3u8Settings$TransportStreamId: The value of the transport stream ID field in the Program Map Table.
refs.M3u8Settings$VideoPid: Packet Identifier (PID) of the elementary video stream in the transport stream. Can be entered as a decimal or hexadecimal value.
refs.Mp2Settings$Channels: Set Channels to specify the number of channels in this output audio track. Choosing Mono in the console will give you 1 output channel; choosing Stereo will give you 2. In the API, valid values are 1 and 2.
refs.Mpeg2Settings$Bitrate: Average bitrate in bits/second. Required for VBR, CBR, and ABR. Five megabits can be entered as 5000000 or 5m. Five hundred kilobits can be entered as 500000 or 0.5m. For MS Smooth outputs, bitrates must be unique when rounded down to the nearest multiple of 1000.
refs.Mpeg2Settings$FramerateNumerator: Framerate numerator - framerate is a fraction, e.g. 24000 / 1001 = 23.976 fps.
refs.Mpeg2Settings$GopClosedCadence: Frequency of closed GOPs. In streaming applications, it is recommended that this be set to 1 so a decoder joining mid-stream will receive an IDR frame as quickly as possible. Setting this value to 0 will break output segmenting.
refs.Mpeg2Settings$HrdBufferInitialFillPercen: Percentage of the buffer that should initially be filled (HRD buffer model).
refs.Mpeg2Settings$HrdBufferSize: Size of buffer (HRD buffer model). Five megabits can be entered as 5000000 or 5m. Five hundred kilobits can be entered as 500000 or 0.5m.
refs.Mpeg2Settings$MaxBitrate: Maximum bitrate in bits/second (for VBR mode only). Five megabits can be entered as 5000000 or 5m. Five hundred kilobits can be entered as 500000 or 0.5m.
refs.Mpeg2Settings$MinIInterval: Enforces separation between repeated (cadence) I-frames and I-frames inserted by Scene Change Detection. If a scene change I-frame is within I-interval frames of a cadence I-frame, the GOP is shrunk and/or stretched to the scene change I-frame. GOP stretch requires enabling lookahead as well as setting I-interval. The normal cadence resumes for the next GOP. This setting is only used when Scene Change Detect is enabled. Note: Maximum GOP stretch = GOP size + Min-I-interval - 1
refs.Mpeg2Settings$NumberBFramesBetweenRefere: Number of B-frames between reference frames.
refs.Mpeg2Settings$Softness: Softness. Selects quantizer matrix, larger values reduce high-frequency content in the encoded image.
refs.MsSmoothGroupSettings$FragmentLength: Use Fragment length (FragmentLength) to specify the mp4 fragment sizes in seconds.  Fragment length must be compatible with GOP size and framerate.
refs.NielsenConfiguration$BreakoutCode: Use Nielsen Configuration (NielsenConfiguration) to set the Nielsen measurement system breakout code. Supported values are 0, 3, 7, and 9.
refs.NoiseReducerFilterSettings$Strength: Relative strength of noise reducing filter. Higher values produce stronger filtering.
refs.NoiseReducerSpatialFilterSettings$PostFi: Specify strength of post noise reduction sharpening filter, with 0 disabling the filter and 3 enabling it at maximum strength.
refs.NoiseReducerSpatialFilterSettings$Speed: The speed of the filter, from -2 (lower speed) to 3 (higher speed), with 0 being the nominal value.
refs.NoiseReducerSpatialFilterSettings$Streng: Relative strength of noise reducing filter. Higher values produce stronger filtering.
refs.ProresSettings$FramerateNumerator: When you use the API for transcode jobs that use framerate conversion, specify the framerate as a fraction. For example,  24000 / 1001 = 23.976 fps. Use FramerateNumerator to specify the numerator of this fraction. In this example, use 24000 for the value of FramerateNumerator.
refs.Rectangle$X: The distance, in pixels, between the rectangle and the left edge of the video frame.
refs.Rectangle$Y: The distance, in pixels, between the rectangle and the top edge of the video frame.
refs.RemixSettings$ChannelsIn: Specify the number of audio channels from your input that you want to use in your output. With remixing, you might combine or split the data in these channels, so the number of channels in your final output might be different.
refs.RemixSettings$ChannelsOut: Specify the number of channels in this output after remixing. Valid values: 1, 2, 4, 6, 8
refs.TimecodeBurnin$FontSize: Use Font Size (FontSize) to set the font size of any burned-in timecode. Valid values are 10, 16, 32, 48.
refs.VideoDescription$FixedAfd: Applies only if you set AFD Signaling(AfdSignaling) to Fixed (FIXED). Use Fixed (FixedAfd) to specify a four-bit AFD value which the service will write on all  frames of this video output.
refs.VideoDescription$Height: Use the Height (Height) setting to define the video resolution height for this output. Specify in pixels. If you don't provide a value here, the service will use the input height.
refs.VideoDescription$Sharpness: Use Sharpness (Sharpness)setting to specify the strength of anti-aliasing. This setting changes the width of the anti-alias filter kernel used for scaling. Sharpness only applies if your output resolution is different from your input resolution, and if you set Anti-alias (AntiAlias) to ENABLED. 0 is the softest setting, 100 the sharpest, and 50 recommended for most content.
refs.VideoDescription$Width: Use Width (Width) to define the video resolution width, in pixels, for this output. If you don't provide a value here, the service will use the input width.
refs.VideoDetail$HeightInPx: Height in pixels for the output
refs.VideoDetail$WidthInPx: Width in pixels for the output
refs.VideoSelector$Pid: Use PID (Pid) to select specific video data from an input file. Specify this value as an integer; the system automatically converts it to the hexidecimal value. For example, 257 selects PID 0x101. A PID, or packet identifier, is an identifier for a set of data in an MPEG-2 transport stream container.
refs.VideoSelector$ProgramNumber: Selects a specific program from within a multi-program transport stream. Note that Quad 4K is not currently supported.
refs.WavSettings$BitDepth: Specify Bit depth (BitDepth), in bits per sample, to choose the encoding quality for this audio track.
refs.WavSettings$Channels: Set Channels to specify the number of channels in this output audio track. With WAV, valid values 1, 2, 4, and 8. In the console, these values are Mono, Stereo, 4-Channel, and 8-Channel, respectively.

refs.AudioDescription$AudioSourceName: Specifies which audio data to use from each input. In the simplest case, specify an "Audio Selector":#inputs-audio_selector by name based on its order within each input. For example if you specify "Audio Selector 3", then the third audio selector will be used from each input. If an input does not have an "Audio Selector 3", then the audio selector marked as "default" in that input will be used. If there is no audio selector marked as "default", silence will be inserted for the duration of that input. Alternatively, an "Audio Selector Group":#inputs-audio_selector_group name may be specified, with similar default/silence behavior. If no audio_source_name is specified, then "Audio Selector 1" will be chosen automatically.
refs.AudioDescription$StreamName: Used for MS Smooth and Apple HLS outputs. Indicates the name displayed by the player (eg. English, or Director Commentary). Alphanumeric characters, spaces, and underscore are legal.
refs.AudioSelector$ExternalAudioFileInput: Specifies audio data from an external file source. Auto populated when Infer External Filename is checked
refs.AvailBlanking$AvailBlankingImage: Blanking image to be used. Leave empty for solid black. Only bmp and png images are supported.
refs.CancelJobRequest$Id: The Job ID of the job to be cancelled.
refs.CaptionDescription$CaptionSelectorName: Specifies which "Caption Selector":#inputs-caption_selector to use from each input when generating captions. The name should be of the format "Caption Selector <N>", which denotes that the Nth Caption Selector will be used from each input.
refs.CaptionDescription$LanguageDescription: Human readable information to indicate captions available for players (eg. English, or Spanish). Alphanumeric characters, spaces, and underscore are legal.
refs.CaptionDescriptionPreset$LanguageDescrip: Human readable information to indicate captions available for players (eg. English, or Spanish). Alphanumeric characters, spaces, and underscore are legal.
refs.CreateJobRequest$JobTemplate: When you create a job, you can either specify a job template or specify the transcoding settings individually
refs.CreateJobRequest$Queue: Optional. When you create a job, you can specify a queue to send it to. If you don't specify, the job will go to the default queue. For more about queues, see the User Guide topic at http://docs.aws.amazon.com/mediaconvert/latest/ug/what-is.html.
refs.CreateJobRequest$Role: Required. The IAM role you use for creating this job. For details about permissions, see the User Guide topic at the User Guide at http://docs.aws.amazon.com/mediaconvert/latest/ug/iam-role.html.
refs.CreateJobTemplateRequest$Category: Optional. A category for the job template you are creating
refs.CreateJobTemplateRequest$Description: Optional. A description of the job template you are creating.
refs.CreateJobTemplateRequest$Name: The name of the job template you are creating.
refs.CreateJobTemplateRequest$Queue: Optional. The queue that jobs created from this template are assigned to. If you don't specify this, jobs will go to the default queue.
refs.CreatePresetRequest$Category: Optional. A category for the preset you are creating.
refs.CreatePresetRequest$Description: Optional. A description of the preset you are creating.
refs.CreatePresetRequest$Name: The name of the preset you are creating.
refs.CreateQueueRequest$Description: Optional. A description of the queue you are creating.
refs.CreateQueueRequest$Name: The name of the queue you are creating.
refs.DashIsoGroupSettings$BaseUrl: A partial URI prefix that will be put in the manifest (.mpd) file at the top level BaseURL element. Can be used if streams are delivered from a different URL than the manifest file.
refs.DashIsoGroupSettings$Destination: Use Destination (Destination) to specify the S3 output location and the output filename base. Destination accepts format identifiers. If you do not specify the base filename in the URI, the service will use the filename of the input file. If your job has multiple inputs, the service uses the filename of the first input file.
refs.DeleteJobTemplateRequest$Name: The name of the job template to be deleted.
refs.DeletePresetRequest$Name: The name of the preset to be deleted.
refs.DeleteQueueRequest$Name: The name of the queue to be deleted.
refs.DescribeEndpointsRequest$NextToken: Use this string, provided with the response to a previous request, to request the next batch of endpoints.
refs.DescribeEndpointsResponse$NextToken: Use this string to request the next batch of endpoints.
refs.DvbNitSettings$NetworkName: The network name text placed in the network_name_descriptor inside the Network Information Table. Maximum length is 256 characters.
refs.DvbSdtSettings$ServiceName: The service name placed in the service_descriptor in the Service Description Table. Maximum length is 256 characters.
refs.DvbSdtSettings$ServiceProviderName: The service provider name placed in the service_descriptor in the Service Description Table. Maximum length is 256 characters.
refs.FileGroupSettings$Destination: Use Destination (Destination) to specify the S3 output location and the output filename base. Destination accepts format identifiers. If you do not specify the base filename in the URI, the service will use the filename of the input file. If your job has multiple inputs, the service uses the filename of the first input file.
refs.FileSourceSettings$SourceFile: External caption file used for loading captions. Accepted file extensions are 'scc', 'ttml', 'dfxp', 'stl', 'srt', and 'smi'. Auto-populated when Infer External Filename is checked.
refs.GetJobRequest$Id: the job ID of the job.
refs.GetJobTemplateRequest$Name: The name of the job template.
refs.HlsEncryptionSettings$ConstantInitializa: This is a 128-bit, 16-byte hex value represented by a 32-character text string. If this parameter is not set then the Initialization Vector will follow the segment number by default.
refs.HlsGroupSettings$BaseUrl: A partial URI prefix that will be prepended to each output in the media .m3u8 file. Can be used if base manifest is delivered from a different URL than the main .m3u8 file.
refs.HlsGroupSettings$Destination: Use Destination (Destination) to specify the S3 output location and the output filename base. Destination accepts format identifiers. If you do not specify the base filename in the URI, the service will use the filename of the input file. If your job has multiple inputs, the service uses the filename of the first input file.
refs.HlsSettings$AudioGroupId: Specifies the group to which the audio Rendition belongs.
refs.HlsSettings$AudioRenditionSets: List all the audio groups that are used with the video output stream. Input all the audio GROUP-IDs that are associated to the video, separate by ','.
refs.HlsSettings$SegmentModifier: String concatenated to end of segment filenames. Accepts "Format Identifiers":#format_identifier_parameters.
refs.Id3Insertion$Id3: Use ID3 tag (Id3) to provide a tag value in base64-encode format.
refs.Id3Insertion$Timecode: Provide a Timecode (TimeCode) in HH:MM:SS:FF or HH:MM:SS;FF format.
refs.Input$FileInput: Use Input (fileInput) to define the source file used in the transcode job. There can be multiple inputs in a job. These inputs are concantenated, in the order they are specified in the job, to create the output.
refs.InputClipping$EndTimecode: Set End timecode (EndTimecode) to the end of the portion of the input you are clipping. The frame corresponding to the End timecode value is included in the clip. Start timecode or End timecode may be left blank, but not both. When choosing this value, take into account your setting for Input timecode source. For example, if you have embedded timecodes that start at 01:00:00:00 and you want your clip to begin five minutes into the video, use 01:00:05:00.
refs.InputClipping$StartTimecode: Set Start timecode (StartTimecode) to the beginning of the portion of the input you are clipping. The frame corresponding to the Start timecode value is included in the clip. Start timecode or End timecode may be left blank, but not both. When choosing this value, take into account your setting for Input timecode source. For example, if you have embedded timecodes that start at 01:00:00:00 and you want your clip to begin five minutes into the video, use 01:00:05:00.
refs.InsertableImage$ImageInserterInput: Use Image location (imageInserterInput) to specify the Amazon S3 location of the image to be inserted into the output. Use a 32 bit BMP, PNG, or TGA file that fits inside the video frame.
refs.InsertableImage$StartTime: Use Start time (StartTime) to specify the video timecode when the image is inserted in the output. This must be in timecode format (HH:MM:SS:FF)
refs.Job$Arn: An identifier for this resource that is unique within all of AWS.
refs.Job$Id: A portion of the job's ARN, unique within your AWS Elemental MediaConvert resources
refs.Job$JobTemplate: The job template that the job is created from, if it is created from a job template.
refs.Job$Queue: Optional. When you create a job, you can specify a queue to send it to. If you don't specify, the job will go to the default queue. For more about queues, see the User Guide topic at http://docs.aws.amazon.com/mediaconvert/latest/ug/what-is.html
refs.Job$Role: The IAM role you use for creating this job. For details about permissions, see the User Guide topic at the User Guide at http://docs.aws.amazon.com/mediaconvert/latest/ug/iam-role.html
refs.JobTemplate$Arn: An identifier for this resource that is unique within all of AWS.
refs.JobTemplate$Category: An optional category you create to organize your job templates.
refs.JobTemplate$Description: An optional description you create for each job template.
refs.JobTemplate$Name: A name you create for each job template. Each name must be unique within your account.
refs.JobTemplate$Queue: Optional. The queue that jobs created from this template are assigned to. If you don't specify this, jobs will go to the default queue.
refs.ListJobTemplatesRequest$Category: Optionally, specify a job template category to limit responses to only job templates from that category.
refs.ListJobTemplatesRequest$NextToken: Use this string, provided with the response to a previous request, to request the next batch of job templates.
refs.ListJobTemplatesResponse$NextToken: Use this string to request the next batch of job templates.
refs.ListJobsRequest$NextToken: Use this string, provided with the response to a previous request, to request the next batch of jobs.
refs.ListJobsRequest$Queue: Provide a queue name to get back only jobs from that queue.
refs.ListJobsResponse$NextToken: Use this string to request the next batch of jobs.
refs.ListPresetsRequest$Category: Optionally, specify a preset category to limit responses to only presets from that category.
refs.ListPresetsRequest$NextToken: Use this string, provided with the response to a previous request, to request the next batch of presets.
refs.ListPresetsResponse$NextToken: Use this string to request the next batch of presets.
refs.ListQueuesRequest$NextToken: Use this string, provided with the response to a previous request, to request the next batch of queues.
refs.ListQueuesResponse$NextToken: Use this string to request the next batch of queues.
refs.Mp4Settings$Mp4MajorBrand: Overrides the "Major Brand" field in the output file. Usually not necessary to specify.
refs.MsSmoothGroupSettings$Destination: Use Destination (Destination) to specify the S3 output location and the output filename base. Destination accepts format identifiers. If you do not specify the base filename in the URI, the service will use the filename of the input file. If your job has multiple inputs, the service uses the filename of the first input file.
refs.NielsenConfiguration$DistributorId: Use Distributor ID (DistributorID) to specify the distributor ID that is assigned to your organization by Neilsen.
refs.Output$Extension: Use Extension (Extension) to specify the file extension for outputs in File output groups. If you do not specify a value, the service will use default extensions by container type as follows * MPEG-2 transport stream, m2ts * Quicktime, mov * MXF container, mxf * MPEG-4 container, mp4 * No Container, the service will use codec extensions (e.g. AAC, H265, H265, AC3)
refs.Output$NameModifier: Use Name modifier (NameModifier) to have the service add a string to the end of each output filename. You specify the base filename as part of your destination URI. When you create multiple outputs in the same output group, Name modifier is required. Name modifier also accepts format identifiers. For DASH ISO outputs, if you use the format identifiers $Number$ or $Time$ in one output, you must use them in the same way in all outputs of the output group.
refs.Output$Preset: Use Preset (Preset) to specifiy a preset for your transcoding settings. Provide the system or custom preset name. You can specify either Preset (Preset) or Container settings (ContainerSettings), but not both.
refs.OutputGroup$CustomName: Use Custom Group Name (CustomName) to specify a name for the output group. This value is displayed on the console and can make your job settings JSON more human-readable. It does not affect your outputs. Use up to twelve characters that are either letters, numbers, spaces, or underscores.
refs.Preset$Arn: An identifier for this resource that is unique within all of AWS.
refs.Preset$Category: An optional category you create to organize your presets.
refs.Preset$Description: An optional description you create for each preset.
refs.Preset$Name: A name you create for each preset. Each name must be unique within your account.
refs.Queue$Arn: An identifier for this resource that is unique within all of AWS.
refs.Queue$Description: An optional description you create for each queue.
refs.Queue$Name: A name you create for each queue. Each name must be unique within your account.
refs.SpekeKeyProvider$ResourceId: The SPEKE-compliant server uses Resource ID (ResourceId) to identify content.
refs.SpekeKeyProvider$Url: Use URL (Url) to specify the SPEKE-compliant server that will provide keys for content.
refs.StaticKeyProvider$KeyFormat: Relates to DRM implementation. Sets the value of the KEYFORMAT attribute. Must be 'identity' or a reverse DNS string. May be omitted to indicate an implicit value of 'identity'.
refs.StaticKeyProvider$KeyFormatVersions: Relates to DRM implementation. Either a single positive integer version value or a slash delimited list of version values (1/2/3).
refs.StaticKeyProvider$StaticKeyValue: Relates to DRM implementation. Use a 32-character hexidecimal string to specify Key Value (StaticKeyValue).
refs.StaticKeyProvider$Url: Relates to DRM implementation. The location of the license server used for protecting content.
refs.TeletextDestinationSettings$PageNumber: Set pageNumber to the Teletext page number for the destination captions for this output.  This value must be a three-digit hexadecimal string; strings ending in -FF are invalid. If you are passing through the entire set of Teletext data, do not use this field.
refs.TeletextSourceSettings$PageNumber: Use Page Number (PageNumber) to specify the three-digit hexadecimal page number that will be used for Teletext captions. Do not use this setting if you are passing through teletext from the input source to output.
refs.TimecodeBurnin$Prefix: Use Prefix (Prefix) to place ASCII characters before any burned-in timecode. For example, a prefix of "EZ-" will result in the timecode "EZ-00:00:00:00". Provide either the characters themselves or the ASCII code equivalents. The supported range of characters is 0x20 through 0x7e. This includes letters, numbers, and all special characters represented on a standard English keyboard.
refs.TimecodeConfig$Anchor: If you use an editing platform that relies on an anchor timecode, use Anchor Timecode (Anchor) to specify a timecode that will match the input video frame to the output video frame. Use 24-hour format with frame number, (HH:MM:SS:FF) or (HH:MM:SS;FF). This setting ignores framerate conversion. System behavior for Anchor Timecode varies depending on your setting for Timecode source (TimecodeSource). * If Timecode source (TimecodeSource) is set to Specified Start (specifiedstart), the first input frame is the specified value in Start Timecode (Start). Anchor Timecode (Anchor) and Start Timecode (Start) are used calculate output timecode. * If Timecode source (TimecodeSource) is set to Start at 0 (zerobased)  the  first frame is 00:00:00:00. * If Timecode source (TimecodeSource) is set to Embedded (embedded), the  first frame is the timecode value on the first input frame of the input.
refs.TimecodeConfig$Start: Only use when you set Timecode Source (TimecodeSource) to Specified Start (SPECIFIEDSTART). Use Start timecode (Start) to specify the timecode for the initial frame. Use 24-hour format with frame number, (HH:MM:SS:FF) or (HH:MM:SS;FF).
refs.TimecodeConfig$TimestampOffset: Only applies to outputs that support program-date-time stamp. Use Time  stamp offset (TimestampOffset) to overwrite the timecode date without affecting the time and frame number. Provide the new date as a string in the format "yyyy-mm-dd".  To use Time stamp offset, you must also enable Insert program-date-time (InsertProgramDateTime) in the output settings.
refs.UpdateJobTemplateRequest$Category: The new category for the job template, if you are changing it.
refs.UpdateJobTemplateRequest$Description: The new description for the job template, if you are changing it.
refs.UpdateJobTemplateRequest$Name: The name of the job template you are modifying
refs.UpdateJobTemplateRequest$Queue: The new queue for the job template, if you are changing it.
refs.UpdatePresetRequest$Category: The new category for the preset, if you are changing it.
refs.UpdatePresetRequest$Description: The new description for the preset, if you are changing it.
refs.UpdatePresetRequest$Name: The name of the preset you are modifying.
refs.UpdateQueueRequest$Description: The new description for the queue, if you are changing it.
refs.UpdateQueueRequest$Name: The name of the queue you are modifying.

refs.Job$CreatedAt: The time, in Unix epoch format in seconds, when the job got created.
refs.JobTemplate$CreatedAt: The timestamp in epoch seconds for Job template creation.
refs.JobTemplate$LastUpdated: The timestamp in epoch seconds when the Job template was last updated.
refs.Preset$CreatedAt: The timestamp in epoch seconds for preset creation.
refs.Preset$LastUpdated: The timestamp in epoch seconds when the preset was last updated.
refs.Queue$CreatedAt: The timestamp in epoch seconds for queue creation.
refs.Queue$LastUpdated: The timestamp in epoch seconds when the queue was last updated.
refs.Timing$FinishTime: The time, in Unix epoch format, that the transcoding job finished
refs.Timing$StartTime: The time, in Unix epoch format, that transcoding for the job began.
refs.Timing$SubmitTime: The time, in Unix epoch format, that you submitted the job.
